articles.title: Dutch language
articles.context: The Dutch written grammar has simplified over the past 100 years: cases are now mainly used for the pronouns, such as ik (I), mij, me (me), mijn (my), wie (who), wiens (whose: masculine or neuter singular), wier (whose: feminine singular; masculine, feminine or neuter plural). Nouns and adjectives are not case inflected (except for the genitive of proper nouns (names): -s, -'s or -'). In the spoken language cases and case inflections had already gradually disappeared from a much earlier date on (probably the 15th century) as in many continental West Germanic dialects.

- The Dutch written grammar has simplified in the past 100 years, with cases now mainly used for pronouns such as ik (I), mij, me (me), mijn (my), wie (who), wiens (whose: masculine or neuter singular), wier (whose: feminine singular; masculine, feminine or neuter plural). Nouns and adjectives are no longer case inflected (except for the genitive of proper nouns (names): -s, -'s or -'). In the spoken language, cases and case inflections had already gradually disappeared from a much earlier date on (probably the 15th century) as in many continental West Germanic dialects.

articles.title: Paris
articles.context: The music hall and cabaret are famous Paris institutions. The Moulin Rouge was opened in 1889. It was highly visible because of its large red imitation windmill on its roof, and became the birthplace of the dance known as the French Cancan. It helped make famous the singers Mistinguett and dith Piaf and the painter Toulouse-Lautrec, who made posters for the venue. In 1911, the dance hall Olympia Paris invented the grand staircase as a settling for its shows, competing with its great rival, the Folies Bergre, Its stars in the 1920s included the American singer and dancer Josephine Baker. The Casino de Paris presented many famous French singers, including Mistinguett, Maurice Chevalier, and Tino Rossi. Other famous Paris music halls include Le Lido, on the Champs-lyses, opened in 1946; and the Crazy Horse Saloon, featuring strip-tease, dance and magic, opened in 1951. The Olympia Paris has presented Edith Piaf, Marlene Dietrich, Miles Davis, Judy Garland, and the Grateful Dead. A half dozen music halls exist today in Paris, attended mostly visitors to the city.

The Olympia Paris, which was invented in 1911, was another famous Paris music hall that featured the grand staircase for its shows, competing with its rival, the Folies Bergre. Stars such as Josephine Baker, Maurice Chevalier, and Tino Rossi graced the stages of the Casino de Paris in the 1920s. Le Lido, opened in 1946, and the Crazy Horse Saloon, which featured strip-tease, dance, and magic and opened in 1951, are other famous Paris music halls. The Olympia Paris has hosted famous performers such as Edith Piaf, Marlene Dietrich, Miles Davis, Judy Garland, and the Grateful Dead. Today, there are several music halls in Paris, primarily attended by visitors to the city.

The Olympia Paris has hosted a diverse lineup of performers over the years, including Edith Piaf, Marlene Dietrich, Miles Davis, Judy Garland, and the Grateful Dead. articles.context: In July 1956, Nasser unilaterally nationalised the Suez Canal. The response of Anthony Eden, who had succeeded Churchill as Prime Minister, was to collude with France to engineer an Israeli attack on Egypt that would give Britain and France an excuse to intervene militarily and retake the canal. Eden infuriated US President Dwight D. Eisenhower, by his lack of consultation, and Eisenhower refused to back the invasion. Another of Eisenhower's concerns was the possibility of a wider war with the Soviet Union after it threatened to intervene on the Egyptian side. Eisenhower applied financial leverage by threatening to sell US reserves of the British pound and thereby precipitate a collapse of the British currency. Though the invasion force was militarily successful in its objectives, UN intervention and US pressure forced Britain into a humiliating withdrawal of its forces, and Eden resigned.

articles.title: USB
articles.context: Some non-standard USB devices use the 5 V power supply without participating in a proper USB network, which negotiates power draw with the host interface. These are usually called USB decorations.[citation needed] Examples include USB-powered keyboard lights, fans, mug coolers and heaters, battery chargers, miniature vacuum cleaners, and even miniature lava lamps. In most cases, these items contain no digital circuitry, and thus are not standard compliant USB devices. This may cause problems with some computers, such as drawing too much current and damaging circuitry. Prior to the Battery Charging Specification, the USB specification required that devices connect in a low-power mode (100 mA maximum) and communicate their current requirements to the host, which then permits the device to switch into high-power mode.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
USB
Some non-standard USB devices use the 5 V power supply without participating in a proper USB network, which negotiates power draw with the host interface. These are usually called USB decorations.[citation needed] Examples include USB-powered keyboard lights, fans, mug coolers and heaters, battery chargers, miniature vacuum cleaners, and even miniature lava lamps. In most cases, these items contain no digital circuitry, and thus are not standard compliant USB devices. This may cause problems with some computers, such as drawing too much current and damaging circuitry. Prior to the Battery Charging Specification, the USB specification required that devices connect in a low-power mode (100 mA maximum) and communicate their current requirements to the host, which then permits the device to switch into high-power mode.

Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
American Idol
The fourteenth season premiered on January 7, 2015. articles.title: Glacier
articles.context: Before glaciation, mountain valleys have a characteristic "V" shape, produced by eroding water. During glaciation, these valleys are widened, deepened, and smoothed, forming a "U"-shaped glacial valley. The erosion that creates glacial valleys eliminates the spurs of earth that extend across mountain valleys, creating triangular cliffs called truncated spurs. Within glacial valleys, depressions created by plucking and abrasion can be filled by lakes, called paternoster lakes. If a glacial valley runs into a large body of water, it forms a fjord.

completions.text:
Before glaciation, mountain valleys have a distinctive "V" shape, sculpted by the erosive power of flowing water. However, during the process of glaciation, these valleys undergo profound transformations, broadening, deepening, and refining their contours into the characteristic "U"-shaped profile that defines glacial landscapes. This metamorphosis is facilitated by the relentless action of glaciers, which not only carve out the valley but also sweep away the ridges and peaks that once obstructed it, giving rise to striking triangular cliffs known as truncated spurs. Within the confines of these glacial valleys, the process of plucking and abrasion gives rise to irregular basins, some of which become the tranquil havens for freshwater bodies, aptly termed paternoster lakes. In regions where glacial valleys terminate at the edges of vast oceans, this magnificent landform meets the embrace of the sea, giving birth to the majestic fjords that grace our coastal horizons.

The passage has been rewritten to enhance the sensory and descriptive elements, aiming to create a more vivid and engaging portrayal of the glacial landscape. The revised version seeks to evoke a sense of awe and wonder at the transformative power of glacial activity, highlighting the intricate processes that shape the unique topography of these awe-inspiring valleys.

completions.text:
Glacier
Before glaciation, mountain valleys have a characteristic "V" shape, which is produced by eroding water. However, during glaciation, these valleys undergo significant changes, such as widening, deepening, and smoothing, ultimately forming a "U"-shaped glacial valley. This process of erosion eliminates the spurs of earth that typically extend across mountain valleys, resulting in the formation of triangular cliffs known as truncated spurs. Inside glacial valleys, depressions created through plucking and abrasion can fill up with water, creating what are called paternoster lakes. Furthermore, if a glacial valley happens to encounter a large body of water, it can lead to the formation of a fjord.

Another version:
Glacier
Before glaciation, mountain valleys possess a distinct "V" shape, sculpted by the erosive power of water. Nevertheless, during the course of glaciation, these valleys experience transformations that involve widening, deepening, and smoothing, ultimately giving rise to a "U"-shaped glacial valley. This process of erosion also removes the protruding spurs that usually span across mountain valleys, giving way to the formation of triangular cliffs known as truncated spurs. Within the confines of glacial valleys, depressions created through plucking and abrasion can be filled with water, resulting in the presence of paternoster lakes. Additionally, if a glacial valley encounters a large body of water, it has the potential to form a fjord.

Nevertheless, during the course of glaciation, these valleys undergo significant modifications, including widening, deepening, and smoothing, resulting in the formation of a "U"-shaped glacial valley. The process of erosion responsible for these changes also removes the spurs of earth that typically protrude across mountain valleys, giving rise to triangular cliffs known as truncated spurs. Within glacial valleys, depressions created through plucking and abrasion can fill up with water, giving way to the formation of paternoster lakes. Furthermore, if a glacial valley encounters a large body of water, it has the potential to create a fjord.

articles.title: Pharmaceutical industry
articles.context: In 1911 arsphenamine, the first synthetic anti-infective drug, was developed by Paul Ehrlich and chemist Alfred Bertheim of the Institute of Experimental Therapy in Berlin. The drug was given the commercial name Salvarsan. Ehrlich, noting both the general toxicity of arsenic and the selective absorption of certain dyes by bacteria, hypothesized that an arsenic-containing dye with similar selective absorption properties could be used to treat bacterial infections. Arsphenamine was prepared as part of a campaign to synthesize a series of such compounds, and found to exhibit partially selective toxicity. Arsphenamine proved to be the first effective treatment for syphilis, a disease which prior to that time was incurable and led inexorably to severe skin ulceration, neurological damage, and death.[citation needed]

articles.title: John, King of England
articles.context: In the late 12th and early 13th centuries the border and political relationship between England and Scotland was disputed, with the kings of Scotland claiming parts of what is now northern England. John's father, Henry II, had forced William the Lion to swear fealty to him at the Treaty of Falaise in 1174. This had been rescinded by Richard I in exchange for financial compensation in 1189, but the relationship remained uneasy. John began his reign by reasserting his sovereignty over the disputed northern counties. He refused William's request for the earldom of Northumbria, but did not intervene in Scotland itself and focused on his continental problems. The two kings maintained a friendly relationship, meeting in 1206 and 1207, until it was rumoured in 1209 that William was intending to ally himself with Philip II of France. John invaded Scotland and forced William to sign the Treaty of Norham, which gave John control of William's daughters and required a payment of 10,000. This effectively crippled William's power north of the border, and by 1212 John had to intervene militarily to support the Scottish king against his internal rivals.[nb 16] John made no efforts to reinvigorate the Treaty of Falaise, though, and both William and Alexander remained independent kings, supported by, but not owing fealty to, John.

John, King of England
In the later 12th and early 13th centuries, the border and political relationship between England and Scotland were disputed, with the kings of Scotland claiming parts of what is now northern England. John's father, Henry II, had forced William the Lion to swear fealty to him at the Treaty of Falaise in 1174. This had been rescinded by Richard I in exchange for financial compensation in 1189, but the relationship remained uneasy. John began his reign by reasserting his sovereignty over the disputed northern counties. He refused William's request for the earldom of Northumbria, but did not intervene in Scotland itself and focused on his continental problems. The two kings maintained a friendly relationship, meeting in 1206 and 1207, until it was rumoured in 1209 that William was intending to ally himself with Philip II of France. John invaded Scotland and forced William to sign the Treaty of Norham, which gave John control of William's daughters and required a payment of 10,000. This effectively crippled William's power north of the border, and by 1212 John had to intervene militarily to support the Scottish king against his internal rivals.[nb 16] John made no efforts to reinvigorate the Treaty of Falaise, though, and both William and Alexander remained independent kings, supported by, but not owing fealty to, John.

articles.title: Great power
articles.context: Shifts of international power have most notably occurred through major conflicts. The conclusion of the Great War and the resulting treaties of Versailles, St-Germain, Neuilly, Trianon and Svres witnessed the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Japan and the United States as the chief arbiters of the new world order. In the aftermath of World War I the German Empire was defeated, the Austria-Hungarian empire was divided into new, less powerful states and the Russian Empire fell to a revolution. During the Paris Peace Conference, the "Big Four"France, Italy, United Kingdom and the United Statesheld noticeably more power and influence on the proceedings and outcome of the treaties than Japan. The Big Four were leading architects of the Treaty of Versailles which was signed by Germany; the Treaty of St. Germain, with Austria; the Treaty of Neuilly, with Bulgaria; the Treaty of Trianon, with Hungary; and the Treaty of Svres, with the Ottoman Empire. During the decision-making of the Treaty of Versailles, Italy pulled out of the conference because a part of its demands were not met and temporarily left the other three countries as the sole major architects of that treaty, referred to as the "Big Three".

completions.text:
Great Power Shifts
The End of the Great War marked a significant shift in global power, as the victorious nations, including the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Japan, and the United States, emerged as the primary players in the new world order. The defeat of the German Empire, the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire into smaller, weaker states, and the fall of the Russian Empire all contributed to this shift. The Big Four - France, Italy, the United Kingdom, and the United States - played a crucial role in shaping the treaties of Versailles, St-Germain, Neuilly, Trianon, and Svres. Although Japan was also present at these conferences, it held less influence compared to the Big Four.

Rise and Fall of Empires
The conclusion of the Great War led to a dramatic restructuring of international power. The German Empire, once a formidable force, faced defeat, while the Austro-Hungarian Empire disintegrated into smaller, less powerful states. Similarly, the Russian Empire fell to revolution, marking a major turning point in global politics. The Big Four - France, Italy, the United Kingdom, and the United States - emerged as the key architects of the new world order, with significant influence in the decision-making process of the Treaty of Versailles and other subsequent treaties.

Redrawing the Map
The aftermath of the Great War witnessed a profound shift in international power, as the victorious nations - the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Japan, and the United States - assumed a dominant position in the new world order. The defeat of the German Empire, the breakup of the Austro-Hungarian Empire into smaller states, and the collapse of the Russian Empire all contributed to this power shift. The Big Four - France, Italy, the United Kingdom, and the United States - held considerable influence in the creation of the Treaty of Versailles and other important agreements, while Italy temporarily withdrew from the proceedings to pursue its own interests.

Crafting the New Order
The conclusion of the Great War resulted in a significant transformation of international power dynamics. The victorious nations, including the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Japan, and the United States, took on prominent roles in shaping the new world order. The defeat of the German Empire, the fragmentation of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, and the collapse of the Russian Empire all played a part in this power shift. The Big Four - France, Italy, the United Kingdom, and the United States - were instrumental in drafting the Treaty of Versailles and other key treaties, exerting considerable influence over the decision-making process.

articles.title: Uranium
articles.context:
The gas centrifuge process, where gaseous uranium hexafluoride (UF
6) is separated by the difference in molecular weight between 235UF6 and 238UF6 using high-speed centrifuges, is the cheapest and leading enrichment process. The gaseous diffusion process had been the leading method for enrichment and was used in the Manhattan Project. In this process, uranium hexafluoride is repeatedly diffused through a silver-zinc membrane, and the different isotopes of uranium are separated by diffusion rate (since uranium 238 is heavier it diffuses slightly slower than uranium-235). The molecular laser isotope separation method employs a laser beam of precise energy to sever the bond between uranium-235 and fluorine. This leaves uranium-238 bonded to fluorine and allows uranium-235 metal to precipitate from the solution. An alternative laser method of enrichment is known as atomic vapor laser isotope separation (AVLIS) and employs visible tunable lasers such as dye lasers. Another method used is liquid thermal diffusion.

completions.text:
1. Uranium Gas Centrifuge Process: This process involves separating gaseous uranium hexafluoride (UF6) by the difference in molecular weight between 235UF6 and 238UF6 using high-speed centrifuges, making it the cheapest and leading enrichment method.

2. Gaseous Diffusion Process: In this method, uranium hexafluoride is repeatedly diffused through a silver-zinc membrane, and the different isotopes of uranium are separated by diffusion rate due to the slightly slower diffusion of uranium-238 compared to uranium-235.

3. Gaseous Diffusion Process (Manhattan Project): The gaseous diffusion process was the primary method for enrichment during the Manhattan Project, utilizing silver-zinc membranes to separate uranium isotopes through the difference in their diffusion rates.

4. Molecular Laser Isotope Separation: This method uses a laser beam with precise energy to break the bond between uranium-235 and fluorine, allowing uranium-235 metal to precipitate from the solution while leaving uranium-238 bonded to fluorine.

5. Liquid Thermal Diffusion: This method involves separating uranium isotopes through liquid thermal diffusion, where the difference in molecular weight between uranium-235 and uranium-238 is utilized to achieve the separation.

6. Alternative Laser Method for Enrichment: Atomic vapor laser isotope separation (AVLIS) is an alternative laser method for enrichment that employs visible tunable lasers, such as dye lasers, to separate uranium isotopes.

articles.title: Queen (band)
articles.context: In July 1973, Queen finally under a Trident/EMI deal released their eponymous debut album, an effort influenced by the heavy metal and progressive rock of the day. The album was received well by critics; Gordon Fletcher of Rolling Stone said "their debut album is superb", and Chicago's Daily Herald called it an "above average debut". It drew little mainstream attention, and the lead single "Keep Yourself Alive", a Brian May composition, sold poorly. Retrospectively, "Keep Yourself Alive" is cited as the highlight of the album, and in 2008 Rolling Stone ranked it 31st in the "100 Greatest Guitar Songs of All Time", describing it as "an entire album's worth of riffs crammed into a single song". The album was certified gold in the UK and the US.

completions.text:
Queen (band)
July 1973 saw the release of Queen's debut album under a Trident/EMI deal. The album was heavily influenced by contemporary heavy metal and progressive rock genres. Although well-received by critics, such as Gordon Fletcher of Rolling Stone and Chicago's Daily Herald, it garnered little mainstream attention and the lead single "Keep Yourself Alive" failed to make a significant impact in sales. However, retrospectively, "Keep Yourself Alive" has been praised as the standout track of the album, with Rolling Stone ranking it as the 31st greatest guitar song of all time in 2008. The album achieved gold certification in both the UK and the US.
Queen (band)
Queen's eponymous debut album, released in July 1973 under a Trident/EMI deal, showcased the band's influences from heavy metal and progressive rock. While the album received positive reviews from critics like Gordon Fletcher of Rolling Stone and Chicago's Daily Herald, it failed to gain significant mainstream success. Despite this, the album's standout track, "Keep Yourself Alive," has since been recognized as a masterpiece, ranking as the 31st greatest guitar song of all time in 2008. The album achieved gold certification in both the UK and the US.

articles.context: At the inception of the Premier League in 199293, just eleven players named in the starting line-ups for the first round of matches hailed from outside of the United Kingdom or Ireland. By 200001, the number of foreign players participating in the Premier League was 36 per cent of the total. In the 200405 season the figure had increased to 45 per cent. On 26 December 1999, Chelsea became the first Premier League side to field an entirely foreign starting line-up, and on 14 February 2005 Arsenal were the first to name a completely foreign 16-man squad for a match. By 2009, under 40% of the players in the Premier League were English.

Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
Premier League
At the inception of the Premier League in 199293, just eleven players named in the starting line-ups for the first round of matches hailed from outside of the United Kingdom or Ireland. By 200001, the number of foreign players participating in the Premier League was 36 per cent of the total. In the 200405 season the figure had increased to 45 per cent. On 26 December 1999, Chelsea became the first Premier League side to field an entirely foreign starting line-up, and on 14 February 2005 Arsenal were the first to name a completely foreign 16-man squad for a match. By 2009, under 40% of the players in the Premier League were English.

articles.title: Montevideo
articles.context: In the early 1970s (1973, to be particular) when the military junta took over power in Uruguay, art suffered in Montevideo. The art studios went into protest mode, with Rimer Cardillo, one of the country's leading artists, making the National Institute of Fine Arts, Montevideo a "hotbed of resistance". This resulted in the military junta coming down heavily on artists by closing the Fine Art Institute and carting away all the presses and other studio equipment. Consequently, the learning of fine arts was only in private studios run by people who had been let out of jail, in works of printing and on paper and also painting and sculpture. It resumed much later.

articles.title: British Empire
articles.context: Between 1815 and 1914, a period referred to as Britain's "imperial century" by some historians, around 10,000,000 square miles (26,000,000 km2) of territory and roughly 400 million people were added to the British Empire. Victory over Napoleon left Britain without any serious international rival, other than Russia in central Asia. Unchallenged at sea, Britain adopted the role of global policeman, a state of affairs later known as the Pax Britannica, and a foreign policy of "splendid isolation". Alongside the formal control it exerted over its own colonies, Britain's dominant position in world trade meant that it effectively controlled the economies of many countries, such as China, Argentina and Siam, which has been characterised by some historians as "Informal Empire".

completions.text:
- British Empire (1815-1914): Between 1815 and 1914, the British Empire expanded significantly, adding around 10,000,000 square miles and approximately 400 million people to its territories. This period is often referred to as Britain's "imperial century."
- Pax Britannica: Following victory over Napoleon, Britain emerged as the world's dominant power, with no major international rival, apart from Russia in central Asia. Unmatched at sea, Britain assumed the role of global policeman and maintained a state of peace known as the Pax Britannica.
- Informal Empire: As the formal control over its colonies grew, Britain's dominant position in world trade allowed it to exert influence over the economies of various countries, such as China, Argentina, and Siam, which some historians characterize as "Informal Empire."

What are some key events that occurred during the period referred to as Britain's "imperial century"?
1. The British defeat of Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815, marking the end of the Napoleonic Wars and establishing Britain as a dominant global power.
2. The Great Exhibition of 1851, held in London, which showcased Britain's industrial and commercial achievements and its global influence.
3. The establishment of the British Raj in India in 1858, following the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
4. The acquisition of Egypt by Britain in 1882, which led to the construction of the Suez Canal and the establishment of a British presence in the Middle East.
5. The Boer Wars in South Africa (1899-1902), which resulted in Britain's control over the territory and the eventual formation of the Union of South Africa in 1910.
6. The partition of India and the creation of Pakistan in 1947, marking the end of the British Raj in India and the beginning of the decolonization process.
7. The Anglo-Irish Treaty of 1921, which led to the formation of the Irish Free State and the partition of Ireland.

How did Britain's position as a global policeman contribute to the expansion of its empire?
Britain's position as a global policeman played a significant role in the expansion of its empire in several ways:

1. Protection of British interests: As the global policeman, Britain's primary responsibility was to protect its own interests and those of its allies. This often involved maintaining order and stability in various regions, which allowed Britain to establish and maintain its empire.

2. Influence in international affairs: Britain's role as a global policeman gave it significant influence in international affairs. This influence allowed Britain to shape global events and policies, which in turn facilitated the expansion of its empire.

3. Naval power: Britain's dominance at sea, thanks to its powerful navy, allowed it to project power and influence globally. This naval power enabled Britain to control key trade routes and protect its interests, which was crucial for the expansion of its empire.

4. Diplomatic relationships: As a global policeman, Britain had strong diplomatic relationships with other nations. These relationships allowed Britain to secure alliances and support for its imperial endeavors, as well as to negotiate favorable trade agreements and territories.

5. Economic dominance: Britain's position as a global policeman also contributed to its economic dominance. By maintaining order and stability, Britain created a favorable environment for trade and commerce, which helped to establish its economic influence and further expand its empire.

Overall, Britain's position as a global policeman provided it with the necessary power, influence, and stability to expand its empire and maintain its position as a dominant global power.

articles.title: Josip Broz Tito
articles.context: In 1966 an agreement with the Vatican, fostered in part by the death in 1960 of anti-communist archbishop of Zagreb Aloysius Stepinac and shifts in the church's approach to resisting communism originating in the Second Vatican Council, accorded new freedom to the Yugoslav Roman Catholic Church, particularly to catechize and open seminaries. The agreement also eased tensions, which had prevented the naming of new bishops in Yugoslavia since 1945. Tito's new socialism met opposition from traditional communists culminating in conspiracy headed by Aleksandar Rankovi. In the same year Tito declared that Communists must henceforth chart Yugoslavia's course by the force of their arguments (implying an abandonment of Leninist orthodoxy and development of liberal Communism). The State Security Administration (UDBA) saw its power scaled back and its staff reduced to 5000.

completions.text:
1. 1966 brought about an agreement with the Vatican, which was partly influenced by the 1960 death of anti-communist Archbishop of Zagreb Aloysius Stepinac and changes in the church's approach to resisting communism, stemming from the Second Vatican Council. This agreement granted new freedoms to the Yugoslav Roman Catholic Church, including the ability to catechize and open seminaries. Additionally, it eased tensions that had prevented the naming of new bishops in Yugoslavia since 1945. Tito's new socialism faced opposition from traditional communists, which eventually led to a conspiracy led by Aleksandar Rankovi. In the same year, Tito declared that Communists should now chart Yugoslavia's course using the power of their arguments, implying an abandonment of Leninist orthodoxy and the development of liberal communism. Consequently, the State Security Administration (UDBA) saw its power reduced, and its staff was decreased to 5000.

articles.title: Melbourne
articles.context: The city reaches south-east through Dandenong to the growth corridor of Pakenham towards West Gippsland, and southward through the Dandenong Creek valley, the Mornington Peninsula and the city of Frankston taking in the peaks of Olivers Hill, Mount Martha and Arthurs Seat, extending along the shores of Port Phillip as a single conurbation to reach the exclusive suburb of Portsea and Point Nepean. In the west, it extends along the Maribyrnong River and its tributaries north towards Sunbury and the foothills of the Macedon Ranges, and along the flat volcanic plain country towards Melton in the west, Werribee at the foothills of the You Yangs granite ridge south west of the CBD. The Little River, and the township of the same name, marks the border between Melbourne and neighbouring Geelong city.

articles.title: Virgil
articles.context: Critics of the Aeneid focus on a variety of issues. The tone of the poem as a whole is a particular matter of debate; some see the poem as ultimately pessimistic and politically subversive to the Augustan regime, while others view it as a celebration of the new imperial dynasty. Virgil makes use of the symbolism of the Augustan regime, and some scholars see strong associations between Augustus and Aeneas, the one as founder and the other as re-founder of Rome. A strong teleology, or drive towards a climax, has been detected in the poem. Virgil
Critics of the Aeneid focus on a variety of issues. The tone of the poem as a whole is a particular matter of debate; some see the poem as ultimately pessimistic and politically subversive to the Augustan regime, while others view it as a celebration of the new imperial dynasty. Virgil makes use of the symbolism of the Augustan regime, and some scholars see strong associations between Augustus and Aeneas, the one as founder and the other as re-founder of Rome. A strong teleology, or drive towards a climax, has been detected in the poem. The Aeneid is full of prophecies about the future of Rome, the deeds of Augustus, his ancestors, and famous Romans, and the Carthaginian Wars; the shield of Aeneas even depicts Augustus' victory at Actium against Mark Antony and Cleopatra VII in 31 BC. A further focus of study is the character of Aeneas. As the protagonist of the poem, Aeneas seems to waver constantly between his emotions and commitment to his prophetic duty to found Rome; critics note the breakdown of Aeneas' emotional control in the last sections of the poem where the "pious" and "righteous" Aeneas mercilessly slaughters Turnus.

articles.title: Frdric Chopin
articles.context: From 1842 onwards, Chopin showed signs of serious illness. After a solo recital in Paris on 21 February 1842, he wrote to Grzymaa: "I have to lie in bed all day long, my mouth and tonsils are aching so much." He was forced by illness to decline a written invitation from Alkan to participate in a repeat performance of the Beethoven Seventh Symphony arrangement at Erard's on 1 March 1843. Late in 1844, Charles Hall visited Chopin and found him "hardly able to move, bent like a half-opened penknife and evidently in great pain", although his spirits returned when he started to play the piano for his visitor. Chopin's health continued to deteriorate, particularly from this time onwards. Modern research suggests that apart from any other illnesses, he may also have suffered from temporal lobe epilepsy.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
Frdric Chopin
From 1842 onwards, Chopin showed signs of serious illness. After a solo recital in Paris on 21 February 1842, he wrote to Grzymaa: "I have to lie in bed all day long, my mouth and tonsils are aching so much." He was forced by illness to decline a written invitation from Alkan to participate in a repeat performance of the Beethoven Seventh Symphony arrangement at Erard's on 1 March 1843. Late in 1844, Charles Hall visited Chopin and found him "hardly able to move, bent like a half-opened penknife and evidently in great pain", although his spirits returned when he started to play the piano for his visitor. Chopin's health continued to deteriorate, particularly from this time onwards. Modern research suggests that apart from any other illnesses, he may also have suffered from temporal lobe epilepsy.

articles.title: Valencia
articles.context: During the regency of Maria Cristina, Espartero ruled Spain for two years as its 18th Prime Minister from 16 September 1840 to 21 May 1841. Under his progressive government the old regime was tenuously reconciled to his liberal policies. During this period of upheaval in the provinces he declared that all the estates of the Church, its congregations, and its religious orders were national propertythough in Valencia, most of this property was subsequently acquired by the local bourgeoisie. City life in Valencia carried on in a revolutionary climate, with frequent clashes between liberals and republicans, and the constant threat of reprisals by the Carlist troops of General Cabrera.

articles.context: Financial problems and a reduction in tourism led to Norfolk Island's administration appealing to the Australian federal government for assistance in 2010. In return, the islanders were to pay income tax for the first time but would be eligible for greater welfare benefits. However, by May 2013 agreement had not been reached and islanders were having to leave to find work and welfare. An agreement was finally signed in Canberra on 12 March 2015 to replace self-government with a local council but against the wishes of the Norfolk Island government. articles.title: Protestantism
articles.context: Protestantism has had an important influence on science. According to the Merton Thesis, there was a positive correlation between the rise of English Puritanism and German Pietism on the one hand and early experimental science on the other. The Merton Thesis has two separate parts: Firstly, it presents a theory that science changes due to an accumulation of observations and improvement in experimental technique and methodology; secondly, it puts forward the argument that the popularity of science in 17th-century England and the religious demography of the Royal Society (English scientists of that time were predominantly Puritans or other Protestants) can be explained by a correlation between Protestantism and the scientific values. Merton focused on English Puritanism and German Pietism as having been responsible for the development of the scientific revolution of the 17th and 18th centuries. He explained that the connection between religious affiliation and interest in science was the result of a significant synergy between the ascetic Protestant values and those of modern science. Protestant values encouraged scientific research by allowing science to identify God's influence on the worldhis creationand thus providing a religious justification for scientific research.

completions.text:
Protestantism has made significant contributions to the field of science. As per the Merton Thesis, there exists a positive correlation between the rise of English Puritanism and German Pietism and the growth of early experimental science. The Merton Thesis consists of two parts: first, it posits that scientific progress is driven by an accumulation of observations and improvements in experimental techniques and methodologies; second, it argues that the rise of science in 17th-century England and the religious makeup of the Royal Society (English scientists at that time were predominantly Puritans or other Protestants) can be attributed to a connection between Protestantism and scientific values. According to Merton, Protestantism and modern science shared a significant synergy, as Protestant values promoted scientific research by allowing scientists to identify God's influence on the world, which provided a religious justification for scientific inquiry.

Furthermore, the Protestant emphasis on individualism and questioning authority aligned with the scientific pursuit of knowledge, leading to a sense of curiosity and exploration. This encouraged scientists to challenge established beliefs and conduct experiments to understand the natural world better. Additionally, the Protestant work ethic, which emphasized hard work and productivity, also contributed to the development of science, as it instilled a dedication and commitment to scientific research among individuals.

Moreover, the Protestant belief in the inherent goodness of the world, as created by God, fostered an appreciation for the natural sciences. It encouraged the study and understanding of God's creation, leading to advancements in fields such as botany, zoology, and astronomy. The Protestant emphasis on reason and empirical evidence further solidified the connection between religion and science, as scientific discoveries were seen as a way to understand and interpret the divine.

In conclusion, Protestantism played a crucial role in shaping the scientific revolution of the 17th and 18th centuries. The synergy between Protestant values and scientific values created a supportive environment for scientific inquiry and contributed to the development of modern science. The Protestant emphasis on individualism, questioning authority, hard work, and understanding God's creation all played a significant role in the advancement of scientific knowledge.

articles.title: Nigeria
articles.context: According to a 2001 report from The World Factbook by CIA, about 50% of Nigeria's population is Muslim, 40% are Christians and 10% adhere to local religions. But in some recent report, the Christian population is now sightly larger than the Muslim population. An 18 December 2012 report on religion and public life by the Pew Research Center stated that in 2010, 49.3 percent of Nigeria's population was Christian, 48.8 percent was Muslim, and 1.9 percent were followers of indigenous and other religions, or unaffiliated. Additionally, the 2010s census of Association of Religion Data Archives has reported that 46.5 percent of the total population is Christian, slightly bigger than the Muslim population of 45.5 percent, and that 7.7 percent are members of other religious groups.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
Iranian languages
The other directly attested Old Iranian dialects are the two forms of Avestan, which take their name from their use in the Avesta, the liturgical texts of indigenous Iranian religion that now goes by the name of Zoroastrianism but in the Avesta itself is simply known as vohu daena (later: behdin). The language of the Avesta is subdivided into two dialects, conventionally known as "Old (or 'Gathic') Avestan", and "Younger Avestan". These terms, which date to the 19th century, are slightly misleading since 'Younger Avestan' is not only much younger than 'Old Avestan', but also from a different geographic region. The Old Avestan dialect is very archaic, and at roughly the same stage of development as Rigvedic Sanskrit. On the other hand, Younger Avestan is at about the same linguistic stage as Old Persian, but by virtue of its use as a sacred language retained its "old" characteristics long after the Old Iranian languages had yielded to their Middle Iranian stage. Unlike Old Persian, which has Middle Persian as its known successor, Avestan has no clearly identifiable Middle Iranian stage (the effect of Middle Iranian is indistinguishable from effects due to other causes).

articles.title: Insect
articles.context: In some cultures, insects, especially deep-fried cicadas, are considered to be delicacies, while in other places they form part of the normal diet. Insects have a high protein content for their mass, and some authors suggest their potential as a major source of protein in human nutrition.:1013 In most first-world countries, however, entomophagy (the eating of insects), is taboo. Since it is impossible to entirely eliminate pest insects from the human food chain, insects are inadvertently present in many foods, especially grains. Food safety laws in many countries do not prohibit insect parts in food, but rather limit their quantity. According to cultural materialist anthropologist Marvin Harris, the eating of insects is taboo in cultures that have other protein sources such as fish or livestock.

* **Insects in Our Food Chain**

Insects, particularly pests like cicadas, can be found in many foods, especially grains. Food safety laws in various countries allow a limited presence of insect parts in food, as it's nearly impossible to completely eradicate them from the food chain. This raises questions about the acceptability of insects as a regular part of human nutrition.

* **The Dual Nature of Insects in Human Diet**

Some cultures celebrate insects, like deep-fried cicadas, as culinary treats, while others shun them as taboo. With their high protein content, insects have the potential to become a major source of nutrition. However, despite this, entomophagy remains a controversial practice in many first-world countries.

* **Insects: A Lingering Taboo**

Even though insects are an inherent part of the human food chain, containing insects in food is generally not seen as a problem. Food safety laws allow a certain level of insect parts in food, but the practice of consuming insects (entomophagy) is still considered taboo in many first-world countries.

completions.text:
"In some cultures, insects, especially deep-fried cicadas, are considered to be delicacies, while in other places they form part of the normal diet. Insects have a high protein content for their mass, and some authors suggest their potential as a major source of protein in human nutrition.:1013 In most first-world countries, however, entomophagy (the eating of insects), is taboo. Since it is impossible to entirely eliminate pest insects from the human food chain, insects are inadvertently present in many foods, especially grains. Food safety laws in many countries do not prohibit insect parts in food, but rather limit their quantity. According to cultural materialist anthropologist Marvin Harris, the eating of insects is taboo in cultures that have other protein sources such as fish or livestock."

"Insects, particularly deep-fried cicadas, are enjoyed as delicacies in some cultures, while they are a common part of the diet in others. These small creatures are known for their high protein content, which some researchers believe could play a significant role in human nutrition. However, in most first-world countries, the consumption of insects, or entomophagy, is considered taboo. Despite this, it is virtually impossible to completely rid the food chain of pest insects, and as a result, they can be found in many foods, especially grains. Insect parts are not explicitly banned in many countries' food safety laws; instead, there are restrictions on their quantity. Cultural materialist anthropologist Marvin Harris suggests that the eating of insects is taboo in cultures that have alternative protein sources, such as fish or livestock."

Every computer program you've ever used.
Every computer program you've ever used is a collection of instructions and data that tells the computer what to do and how to perform tasks. These programs are created by software developers using programming languages such as Java, Python, C++, and others. They can range from simple applications like word processors and calculators to complex systems like operating systems and video games.

The programs you use are like a recipe for cooking. Just as a recipe tells you what ingredients to use and how to mix them together to create a delicious meal, a program provides a set of instructions for the computer to follow in order to complete a specific task or solve a problem. These instructions are written in a way that the computer can understand and interpret, allowing it to carry out the desired actions.

Every time you open a program, the computer reads and executes the instructions contained within that program, using the hardware components (such as the processor, memory, and input/output devices) to perform the necessary operations. As you interact with the program (by clicking on buttons, typing text, or other actions), the program continues to interpret and execute the instructions accordingly, allowing you to accomplish your desired tasks.

From the simple word processors and web browsers you use daily, to the more complex software used in industries such as finance, medicine, and engineering, every computer program you've ever used is a testament to the power and versatility of modern computing technology.

Here are some additional examples of computer programs you may have used:

- Microsoft Word: A word processing software used for creating and editing documents.
- Google Chrome: A web browser for accessing and navigating the internet.
- Photoshop: A graphic design software used for editing and manipulating images.
- Spotify: A music streaming service that allows you to listen to and organize your music collection.
- Adobe Photoshop: A digital image editing and manipulation software used by professionals and hobbyists alike.
- Microsoft Excel: A spreadsheet software used for organizing and analyzing data.
- Notepad: A basic text editor included with most operating systems, often used for writing simple text files.
- Skype: A video communication software that allows you to make voice and video calls, as well as chat with friends and family.
- Microsoft Outlook: An email and calendar software used for managing your digital correspondence and scheduling appointments.
- Adobe After Effects: A professional-grade motion graphics and visual effects software used by filmmakers, designers, and advertisers.
- Steam: A digital distribution platform for purchasing and playing video games on your computer.

These are just a few examples of the vast array of computer programs available, each designed to fulfill specific needs and enhance your computing experience.

articles.title: Botany
articles.context: The root system and the shoot system are interdependent  the usually nonphotosynthetic root system depends on the shoot system for food, and the usually photosynthetic shoot system depends on water and minerals from the root system. Cells in each system are capable of creating cells of the other and producing adventitious shoots or roots. Stolons and tubers are examples of shoots that can grow roots. Roots that spread out close to the surface, such as those of willows, can produce shoots and ultimately new plants. In the event that one of the systems is lost, the other can often regrow it. In fact it is possible to grow an entire plant from a single leaf, as is the case with Saintpaulia, or even a single cell  which can dedifferentiate into a callus (a mass of unspecialised cells) that can grow into a new plant. In vascular plants, the xylem and phloem are the conductive tissues that transport resources between shoots and roots. Roots are often adapted to store food such as sugars or starch, as in sugar beets and carrots.

1. Botany is the study of plants, which have a complex relationship between their root and shoot systems. The root system, which is typically nonphotosynthetic, relies on the shoot system for food, while the shoot system, which is usually photosynthetic, depends on water and minerals from the root system. Cells in both systems have the capability to generate cells of the other and produce adventitious shoots or roots. Stolons and tubers are examples of shoots that can grow roots. Roots that spread out near the surface, such as those found in willows, can also give rise to shoots and new plants. In cases where one system is lost, the other can often regrow it. In fact, it is possible to grow an entire plant from a single leaf, as demonstrated by Saintpaulia, or even from a single cell, which can dedifferentiate into a callus (a mass of unspecialized cells) that can eventually grow into a new plant. In vascular plants, the xylem and phloem serve as the conductive tissues responsible for transporting resources between the shoots and roots. Additionally, roots are often adapted to store various resources, such as sugars or starch, as seen in sugar beets and carrots.
